#Text=Ludovico Roncalli
#Text=Count Ludovico Giuseppe Antonio Filippo Roncalli , or simply Count Ludovico ( 1654 – 1713 ) , was an Italian composer .
#Text=Roncalli was born in Bergamo on 6 March 1654 and baptized at the church of San Pancrazio in the Città Alta in Bergamo on 8 June 1654 .
#Text=He was the younger son of Conte Giovanni Martino Roncalli ( 1626 – 1700 ) and brother of Francesco , Conte di Montorio ( 1645 – 1717 ) .
#Text=He was ordained to the priesthood and died in Bergamo on 25 August 1713 .
#Text=The Roncalli family still possess a portrait of him in clerical dress ( Dell'Ara and Parimbelli 2004 , 17 ) .
#Text=A note on the back of the painting reads " Comes Ludovicus Roncalius I.V.D. [ Iuris Utriusque Doctor ) et abbas , et suis legatis ad Sancta exercitia promovenda insignis largitur .

column1: #Text=The portrait is reproduced in Dell'Ara 's article and in the liner notes to the recordings of Jorge Oraison and Giacomo Parimbelli .
#Text=A letter written by his brother Francesco to padre Martino is preserved in family archives .
#Text=It refers to financial assistance given to Ludovico whilst he was in Rome in 1695 .
#Text=His reasons for visiting Rome are unknown but he may have been introduced to musical circles there by Cardinal Pamphilli to whom Capricci armonici is dedicated .
#Text=He published a collection of nine suites for five-course baroque guitar , Capricci armonici sopra la chitarra spagnola ( " Harmonic caprices for the Spanish guitar " ) , in 1692 .

column1: #Text=This is dedicated to the well-known patron of music , Cardinal Benedetto Panfili , a great-grandson of Pope Innocent X who was Cardinal Legate in Bologna from 1690 and later librarian of the Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana in Rome ( Dell'Ara and Parimbelli 2004 , 17 ) .
#Text=It was transcribed into modern notation and arranged for the six-string guitar by Oscar Chilesotti in 1881 .

#Text=The work consists of nine complete suites , each comprising a preludio and alemanda followed by some of the other seventeenth-century dance forms such as corrente , sarabanda , gigue , minuet and gavotta .
#Text=The last movement of the ninth suite is a passacaglia which was orchestrated by Ottorino Respighi and included in his Ancient Airs and Dances Suite no . 3 .
#Text=Roncalli 's music is a great favorite of guitar enthusiasts , and individual movements frequently appear in guitar method books .

#Text=Frederick Noad , who compiled an anthology titled The Baroque Guitar , as well as other popular instruction books , did not rate the Chilesotti transcription highly , pointing to many omitted embellishments and octave errors relating to the fourth and fifth strings ( Noad 1974 , 29 ) .

#Text=Roncalli probably used a bourdon or low octave string only on the fourth course with the fifth course re-entrant – a method of stringing particularly associated with his compatriot Francesco Corbetta and widely used in the later part of the seventeenth century – e ' bb gg dd ' aa .
#Text=Another edition in modern notation was published by Bruno Henze , and released in 1955 by VEB Friedrich Hofmeister , Leipzig .
#Text=Noad did not comment on whether this edition had corrected the deficiencies of the Chilesotti version .
#Text=The original is available in two facsimile editions , both published in 1979 .
#Text=Roncalli 's Capricci armonici sopra la chitarra spagnola has been the exclusive subject of several recent recordings .
#Text=One of the first was Sandro Volta 's of suites I , II , IV , V , VII , and VIII on the Arion label in 1994 ( ARN 68336 ) .
#Text=Jorge Oraisón recorded the entire cycle on 2 CDs for Vanguard Classics in 1996 ( 99151 ) .
#Text=Richard Savino recorded suites I , II , III , V , VII , and VIII for Dorian in 2008 ( DSL-90604 ) .
#Text=Volta , Oraisón , and Savino used five-course guitars for their Roncalli recordings .
#Text=In 2004 another recording devoted exclusively to Roncalli 's work was released on the Italian label Tactus .
#Text=It features Giacomo Parimbelli performing the complete suites except for V , VI , and IX , on a 19th-century instrument .
